content.description: Low start with a good right facing hold and a small left hand crimp.  Make a couple of hard moves to the good rail system, then traverse right a few moves and top out into the corner.  Probably v3-4ish from starting on the rail.
content.location: Right side of the long overhanging face.

content.description: Stand start compressing the arete facing land.  A lower start looks possible, but will be very hard.
content.location: Obvious compression arete on the east side facing shore.

content.description: Nice easy warm up route. The climb goes straight up. Standing start. Start with hands on obvious holds near chest level more towards the right. The crux would be finding the jug at the lip of the boulder. No real technical moves.
content.location: Look for a diamond like shape in the rock.

content.description: Awesome and striking line with great hand holds and a huge over hang. Foot holds are small and the route requires many heel hooks. There are a couple variations to this route but the main line goes to left until you can manage to get over the lip of the boulder. The second variation is a left handed dyno to the lip but that is likely to cut your hand. This rock grips really well but is rough and sharp in some places.
content.location: Go to the obvious huge over hang. Start towards the bottom of the lower crack where there’s a good right foot. Work your way left up the crack.

content.description: This is the first and biggest boulder in an area of about 6 big boulders. The first first 12 feet provide good technical climbing, after that it’s a walk up to the top.
